(section)'', 580 U.S. ___ (2017) | courtlistener =https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/4377349/star-athletica-l-l-c-v-varsity-brands-inc/ | cornell = https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/15-866 | googlescholar = https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=3822888794493391837 | justia = https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/580/15-866 }} *[http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/star-athletica-llc-v-varsity-brands-inc/ SCOTUSblog case page]
[[Category:2017 in United States case law]] [[Category:United States copyright case law]] [[Category:United States Supreme Court cases]] [[Category:United States Supreme Court cases of the Roberts Court]] [[Category:Cheerleading]] [[Category:Fashion design]]

{{About||the 1950 MGM film with Gene Kelly and Judy Garland|Summer Stock|the Canadian conservatory|Summerstock Conservatory}}
In American theater, '''summer stock theatre''' is a [[theater (structure)|theatre]] that presents stage productions only in the summer. The name combines the season with the tradition of staging shows by a resident company, reusing [[repertory|stock]] [[theatrical scenery|scenery]] and [[costume]]s. Summer stock theatres frequently take advantage of seasonal weather by having their productions outdoors or under tents set up temporarily for their use.
Some smaller theatres still continue this tradition, and a few summer stock theatres have become highly regarded by both patrons as well as performers and designers. [[Actors' Equity Association|Equity]] status and pay for actors in these theatres varies greatly. Often viewed as a starting point for professional actors, stock casts are typically young, just out of high school or still in college.
==History== Summer stock started in 1919-1920s with four theatres: [[The Muny]], St. Louis, Mo. (1919) is the nation's oldest and largest outdoor musical theatre; Manhattan Theatre Colony, first started near [[Peterborough, New Hampshire]] (1927) and moved to [[Ogunquit, Maine]]; the Cape Playhouse, [[Dennis, Massachusetts]] (1927); and the Berkshire Playhouse, [[Stockbridge, Massachusetts]] (1928). Many of the theatres of the [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/heyday heyday], the 1920s through the 1960s, were in New England. Part of the "straw hat circuit," theatres also were in New York, Pennsylvania, and Ohio, among other states. (There had been earlier summer theatres: the Gardens Theatre, [[Denver]] (1890) and Lakewood Playhouse near Skowhegan, [[Maine]] (1901 for summer), but they were established stock theatres that had then been used as a summer venue.)<ref name=Wilmeth629>Wilmeth, p. 629</ref>
The structure was to present different plays in weekly or biweekly repertory, performed by a resident company, generally between June and September. The usual fare consisted of light comedies, romances and mysteries. The theatres were located in rural areas.<ref name=Wilmeth629/> Touring companies would carry hand props and costumes to each venue, where sound, lights and set would be awaiting them.
Summer stock provided a training ground for actors and inexpensive entertainment for vacationing East Coast urbanites. Craig Mamrick describes [[Louis Edmonds]]' early summer stock experience: "Louis spent the summer of 1949 working as part of the repertory company at the Ogunquit Playhouse in Ogunquit, Maine...The Ogunquit Playhouse was affiliated with the Manhattan Theatre Colony, an apprentice program that hopeful actors could attend (paying $150 for the summer) to learn their craft and observe—and possibly work with—professionals. Such stage luminaries as Maude Adams, Ethel Barrymore, Lilian Gish, and Ruth Gordon had trod the boards here. Students took classes in acting, stagecraft, makeup, and voice, and if they were talented enough, they might be asked to appear in plays with the resident acting company."<ref>Hamrick, Craig. ''Big Lou'' (2004), iUniverse, {{ISBN|0-595-29716-1}}, p. 18</ref> Additionally, many notable performers spent their summers on the circuit. Plays and musicals that had closed on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] would play the circuit. By 1950, there were 152 Equity companies, including the Ogunquit Playhouse<ref name=ogunquit>[http://www.ogunquitplayhouse.org/ Ogunquit Playhouse official site] ogunquitplayhouse.org, accessed July 22, 2009</ref> and Skowhegan Playhouse in Maine; the [[Woodstock, New York|Woodstock]] Playhouse and the [[Forestburgh, New York|Forestburgh]] Playhouse in upstate New York; [[Falmouth, Massachusetts|Falmouth]] Playhouse in Massachusetts (burned down in 1994);<ref>McLaughlin, Jeff.[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8268530.html Article summary: "Predawn fire destroys Falmouth Playhouse, a summer tradition", ''The Boston Globe''] highbeam.com, March 1, 1994, accessed July 22, 2009</ref> [[Priscilla Beach Theatre]] in [[Plymouth, Massachusetts]], and the Bucks County Playhouse in [[New Hope, Pennsylvania|New Hope]] (suburban Philadelphia), Pennsylvania (established in 1939).<ref>"Before the theater fell on hard times in the 1970s...it was part of the straw-hat circuit that showcased stage and screen stars in the summer." D'Alessandro, Gene. "Bucks County Playhouse owner Ralph Miller is celebrating his career and looking ahead to more", ''The Philadelphia Inquirer'', June 18, 2006, p. L03</ref> The [[Westport Country Playhouse]] in [[Connecticut]], since renovated with the support of [[Joanne Woodward]] and [[Paul Newman]], was also part of the summer stock circuit.
The circuit toured in [[Florida]] and the Southeast during the winter. Venues included the [[Beacham Theater]] in Orlando and the Royal Poinciana Playhouse in [[Palm Beach, Florida]] (closed since 2004)<ref>Kelly, William.[http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/arts/content/news/plaza/2009/04/15/playhouse0416.html "Town Council willing to allow Royal Poinciana Playhouse demolition,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718232038/http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/arts/content/news/plaza/2009/04/15/playhouse0416.html |date=2011-07-18 }} palmbeachdailynews.com, April 15, 2009</ref> where performers from [[Bob Cummings]] in 1958 to [[Arlene Francis]] (1961) and [[Richard Chamberlain]] (1966) appeared.<ref>[http://www.pbtheaterguild.org/RoyalPoinciana.pdf "Royal Poinciana Playhouse-Merged History, research by Tom Clarie", pp.71-73] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008111153/http://www.pbtheaterguild.org/RoyalPoinciana.pdf |date=2007-10-08 }} pbtheaterguild.org, April 3, 2006</ref>
==Performers== Stars of Broadway, film, and television would regularly spend summers performing in stock. The Council of Stock Theatres (COST) negotiated a special contract with [[Actors Equity]] to cover the work of actors and stage managers.<ref>Armbrust, Roger.[http://www.allbusiness.com/services/amusement-recreation-services/4592680-1.html "Equity-COST Contract Set - Three-year Contract Includes 9-12% Salary Increases,"] allbusiness.com, as published in ''Backstage'', March 26, 1999</ref><ref>[http://www.actorsequity.org/docs/rulebooks/COST_1345_Rulebook_04-08.pdf Actors Equity Association Agreement and ules Governing Employment in Non-Resident Dramatic Stock, Effective: December 27, 2004] actorsequity.org, accessed July 22, 2009</ref>
[[John Kenley]], an [[Ohio]]-based producer, ran his own summer stock circuit, [[Kenley Players]], in [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], [[Dayton, Ohio|Dayton]], [[Warren, Ohio|Warren]], the Carousel Theatre in [[Akron, Ohio|Akron]], and [[Canton, Ohio]], and sent many of the shows to an affiliated theatre in [[Flint, Michigan]]. Starting in 1958 performers such as [[Dan Dailey]] in ''[[Guys and Dolls (musical)|Guys and Dolls]]'', [[Barbara Eden]] in ''[[Lady in the Dark]]'', and [[Howard Keel]] in ''[[Kismet (1955 film)|Kismet]]'' appeared. Kenley cast "movie stars and television personalities" who were nationally known.<ref>Vacha, John. ''The music went 'round and around'', (2004), Kent State University Press, {{ISBN|0-87338-798-8}}, p. 90</ref> During [[Gypsy Rose Lee]]'s engagement in ''[[Auntie Mame]]'' at the Warren theatre, [[Erik Preminger]] wrote: "Working for him [John Kenley] was a joy. Everything about his operation was first-class from the director and supporting cast he had assembled through the scenery, props, and costumes...He was attentive, supportive."<ref>Preminger, Erik Lee. ''My G-string mother'' (2004), Frog Books, {{ISBN|1-58394-096-0}}, p. 172</ref> Performers such as [[Paul Lynde]],<ref>"Names in the News", ''The Associated Press'', Dateline: Akron, Ohio, July 5, 1979</ref> [[Bill Bixby]], [[Karen Morrow]], [[Phyllis Diller]], [[Andy Devine]], [[Gordon MacRae]]<ref>The ''Cincinnati Magazine'' listing for Kenley Players Summer Theatre, shows ''Milk and Honey'' starring Gordon MacRae, week of August 1, 1972, and the remainder of August 1972 [https://books.google.com/books?id=WesCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA20&dq=Kenley+%22Gordon+MacRae%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3 Theatre listings]''Cincinnati Magazine'', August 1972</ref> and [[Patrice Munsel]] starred in Kenley stock productions. [[Ethel Merman]] performed in ''[[Call Me Madam]]'' at the Kenley Players in 1968 (as well as appearing at the Parker Playhouse and [[Coconut Grove Playhouse]] in Miami earlier that year).<ref>Kellow, Brian. ''Ethel Merman'' (2007), Viking, {{ISBN|0-670-01829-5}}, p. 219</ref>
The Cape Playhouse in [[Dennis, Massachusetts]] opened in 1927 with ''The Guardsman'', starring [[Basil Rathbone]], and has continued through the 2009 season with [[Hunter Foster]] and [[Malcolm Gets]].<ref>[http://www.capeplayhouse.com/ Cape Playhouse official site] capeplayhouse.com, accessed July 22, 2009</ref>
The Ogunquit Playhouse, begun in 1933, attracted performers such as [[Maude Adams]], [[Ethel Barrymore]], and [[Laurette Taylor]] in the early years and more recently, [[Sally Struthers]], [[Lucie Arnaz]], and [[Lorenzo Lamas]].<ref name=ogunquit/>
Performers such as [[Ginger Rogers]], [[Douglas Fairbanks Jr.]], [[Angela Lansbury]], [[Bob Hope]], [[Sergio Franchi]], [[Zero Mostel]], [[Ann Miller]], [[Jane Powell]], and [[Debbie Reynolds]] performed at the [[Cape Cod]] Music Circus and its sister theatre, the South Shore Music Circus.<ref name=melody>[http://www.melodytent.org/history.php Cape Cod Melody Tent history] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016063029/https://www.melodytent.org/history.php |date=2011-10-16 }} melodytent.org, accessed June 22, 2009</ref>
[[Colleen Dewhurst]] wrote of her experiences in summer stock as a new actress: "My first professional jobs were in summer stock, in small, medium and large companies that presented ten plays in ten weeks from June until Labor Day...At that time, the core of each summer stock company was made up of a stage manager and six resident actors: a leading man and woman, a character man and woman, and an ingenue and a juvenile. In some cases, five or six of the summer plays would be 'star vehicles', featuring a familiar actor or actress."<ref>Dewhurst, Colleen. ''Colleen Dewhurst'' (2002), Simon and Schuster, {{ISBN|0-7432-4270-X}}, p. 74</ref>
[[William Shatner]] performed in summer stock after the cancellation of ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]''.<ref>[http://www.details.com/celebrities-entertainment/men-of-the-moment/200712/wiseguy-sci-fi-and-star-trek-legend-william-shatner]</ref>
==Notable theatres== Some summer theatres specialize in a particular type of production, such as [[William Shakespeare|Shakespearean]] [[play (theatre)|plays]], [[musical theatre|musicals]], or even [[opera]]. Some notable summer theatres include: [[Oregon Shakespeare Festival]] [[Ashland, Oregon]],<ref>[http://www.osfashland.org/ Oregon Shakespeare Festival official site] osfashland.org, accessed July 22, 2009</ref> Rocky Mountain Repertory Theatre, [[Grand Lake, Colorado]],<ref>[http://www.rockymountainrep.com/ Rocky Mountain Repertory Theatre official site] www.rockymountainrep.com, accessed July 22, 2009 [[Summerstock Conservatory]], [[Calgary]]</ref><ref>[http://www.summerstock.ca/ Summerstock Conservatory official site] summerstock.ca, accessed July 22, 2009</ref> [[Utah Shakespearean Festival]], [[Cedar City, Utah]],<ref>[http://www.bard.org/ Utah Shakespearean Festival official site] bard.org, accessed july 22, 2009</ref> [[Santa Fe Opera]],<ref>[http://www.santafeopera.org/ Santa Fe Opera 2009 Festival Season] santafeopera.org, accessed July 22, 2009</ref> [[Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival]], [[Becket, Massachusetts]],<ref>[http.www.jacobspillow.org/ Jacob's Pillow Official Site]</ref> [[Williamstown Theatre Festival]], [[Williamstown, Massachusetts]],<ref>[http://www.wtfestival.org/ Williamstown Theatre Festival official site] wtfestival.org, accessed july 22, 2009</ref> [[Berkshire Theatre Festival]], [[Stockbridge, Massachusetts]],<ref>[http://www.berkshiretheatre.org/ Berkshire Theatre Festival official site] berkshiretheatre.org, accessed July 22, 2009</ref> [[Glimmerglass Opera]], [[Cooperstown]], New York,<ref>[http://www.glimmerglass.org/ Glimmerglass Opera official site] glimmerglass.org, accessed July 22, 2009</ref> The Barn Theatre in Augusta, Michigan and [[Vancouver]]'s [[Bard on the Beach]].<ref>[http://www.bardonthebeach.org/ Bard on the Beach Shakespeare Festival 2009] bardonthebeach.org, accessed July 22, 2009</ref>
==Circus tent theatre== [[Image:Music Circus tent front.jpg|180px|right|thumb|The Sacramento Music Circus tent in 2001]] In 1949, [[St. John Terrell]] began a new experience presenting summer stock theatre under an arena-type ([[circus]]) tent in [[Lambertville, New Jersey]], the [[Music circus]]. This began a new period of outdoor theatre.<ref>[http://www.lambertville-music-circus.org/ Music Circus archives, history, show/cast lists] lambertville-music-circus.org, accessed July 22, 2009</ref> In 1951 this new style of summer stock made its way west with the addition of the [[California Musical Theatre|Sacramento Music Circus]].
The [[Cape Cod]] Music Circus (now the Melody Tent) in [[Hyannis, Massachusetts|Hyannis]], Massachusetts opened in 1950, the third tent theatre to open, and The South Shore Music Circus in [[Cohasset, Massachusetts|Cohasset]], Massachusetts followed in 1951. A tent theatre had opened earlier in Florida.<ref name=melody/>
[[Image:Music Circus Stage.jpg|180px|left|thumb|The Sacramento Music Circus stage in 2001]] Another theatre in the round, the [[Valley Forge Music Fair]] (which closed in 1996), in Devon, Pennsylvania, was opened in 1955 by [[Shelly Gross]], [[Lee Guber]] and [[Frank Ford (broadcaster)|Frank Ford]]. They then opened other theatres in the round, including Shady Grove Music Fair in Washington, DC, Painters Mill Music Fair in Maryland (closed in 1991), and the [[Westbury Music Fair]] on [[Long Island]], opened in 1956.<ref>[[Simonson, Robert]]. [https://archive.is/20120908022435/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/130436 Shelly Gross, Creator of Summer Stock "Music Fairs," Dies at 88,"] playbill.com, June 22, 2009</ref> By 1957, there were 19 tent theatres, many located in Massachusetts, New York, and New Jersey, and all presenting musicals only. (The musical ''[[The Pajama Game]]'' was the major show making the tent circuit in the summer of 1957.)<ref>Kirby, Irwinn.[https://books.google.com/books?id=gCEEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA79&dq=Beverly+%22North+Shore+Music%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3 "Tented Broadway Grows",] ''The Billboard'', June 24, 1957, accessed July 24, 2009</ref>
The [[theatre in the round]] concept brought Broadway-style musicals to northern [[California]] under a big top tent each summer. Original producers Russell Lewis and Howard Young presented their first production, ''[[Show Boat]]'', the same opening production at both the Lambertville and the South Shore Music Circus. The original Lambertville theatre closed in 1970, and both the Sacramento and South Shore theatres continue to thrive today. In Sacramento, live musicals in the round are presented in a new permanent complex, The [[Wells Fargo Pavilion]]. The South Shore Music Circus and Cape Cod Melody Tent now serve primarily as intimate settings for musical acts including popular singers, oldies groups, and orchestras. {{clear}}
==See also== {{Portal|Theatre}} *[[Regional theatre in the United States]] *[[Repertory]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
*Wilmeth, Don B., Jacobs, Leonard. ''The Cambridge Guide to American Theatre'' (Ed. 2,2007), Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-83538-0}}
==Further reading== *LoMonaco, Martha Schmoyer. ''Summer Stock! An American Theatrical Phenomenon'' (2004), Palgrave Macmillan, {{ISBN|1-4039-6542-0}}
==External links== *[http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080515/GJENTERTAINMENT_01/654560630/-1/FOSNEWS Fosters.com article on Ogunquit Playhouse, May 15, 2008] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=sX1RBCcDD-8C&pg=PA137&lpg=PA137&dq=%22music+circus%22+%22lambertville+new+jersey%22&source=web&ots=Sc8PYBWG86&sig=P2wmTJJlJvVZngoWZn_QOaSGHjM&hl=en ''Sacramento: Indomitable City'' by Steven M. Avella, p. 137, Lambertville and Sacramento Music Circus] *[http://www.themusiccircus.org/ South Shore Music Circus site] *[http://www.summerstock.ca/ The Summerstock Theatre Society] *[http://www.mtwichita.org/ Music Theatre of Wichita]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Summer Stock Theatre}} [[Category:Theatre]] [[Category:Theatrical genres]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Transporter'' (franchise)}} {{More citations needed|date=June 2009}} {{Infobox media franchise |title=''Transporter'' |caption= DVD set containing the first three films |image= Transporter Trilogy cover.jpg |imagesize= |origin= |creator=[[Luc Besson]]
[[Robert Mark Kamen]] |films={{plainlist| *''[[The Transporter]]'' (2002) *''[[Transporter 2]]'' (2005) *''[[Transporter 3]]'' (2008) *''[[The Transporter Refueled]]'' (2015) }} |tv=''[[Transporter: The Series]]'' (2012–2014) |atv= |games= |vgs= |books= |comics= |soundtracks= {{plainlist| *[[The Transporter#Soundtrack|''The Transporter'']] (score) *[[Transporter 2#Soundtrack|''Transporter 2'']] *''Transporter 3'' }} |music= }} '''''Transporter''''' (French: '''''Le Transporteur''''') is an English-language French [[action film]] franchise, comprising four films released between 2002 and 2015, and a television series. [[Jason Statham]] plays Frank Martin in the first three movies, a professional freelance courier driver for hire. Statham himself is an accomplished [[martial artist]], allowing him to do all the combat scenes involving Frank Martin himself. This permits the films' signature Hong Kong-style fight scenes, choreographed by [[Corey Yuen]]. [[Chris Vance (actor)|Chris Vance]] portrays Frank Martin in the [[Transporter: The Series|television series]] and [[Ed Skrein]] portrays Frank Martin in the [[The Transporter Refueled|fourth film]], a [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]]. ==Films== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" width=99% |- ! Crew member ! style="width:25%;" | ''[[The Transporter]]''
(2002) ! style="width:25%;" | ''[[Transporter 2]]''
(2005) ! style="width:25%;" | ''[[Transporter 3]]''
(2008) ! style="width:25%;" | ''[[The Transporter Refueled]]''
(2015) |- ! Director | [[Corey Yuen]] | [[Louis Leterrier]] | [[Olivier Megaton]] | [[Camille Delamarre]] |- ! Producer(s) | colspan="3" | [[Luc Besson]]
Stephen Chasman | Mark Gao
[[Luc Besson]] |- ! Writer(s) | colspan="3" | Luc Besson
[[Robert Mark Kamen]] | Adam Cooper

[[Vincent Tabaillon]] | [[Camille Delamarre]]
Carlo Rizzo | Julien Rey |- ! Cinematographer | Nicolas Trembasiewicz | [[Mitchell Amundsen]] | Giovanni Fiore Coltellacci | Christophe Collette |- ! Production company(s) | [[EuropaCorp]]

Canal+ |- ! Distributor | colspan="2" | [[20th Century Fox]] | [[Lionsgate Films]] | EuropaCorp |- ! Runtime | 92 minutes | 87 minutes | 104 minutes | 96 minutes |- ! Release date | 11 October 2002 | 2 September 2005 | 26 November 2008 | 4 September 2015 |} ===''The Transporter''=== {{Main|The Transporter}} Frank Martin ([[Jason Statham]]) is a highly skilled driver known only as "The Transporter." He will transport anything, no questions asked, always on time, and he is known as the best in the business. He strictly follows three rules when transporting: Rule Number 1: "Once the deal is made, it is final", Rule Number 2: "No names", and Rule Number 3: "Never open the package." Frank inadvertently breaks his own rule, opens the package and finds a bound and gagged woman. ===''Transporter 2''=== {{Main|Transporter 2}} Frank is working as the driver/chauffeur for a wealthy family, in the United States. Martin bonds with their young son, whom he drives to school every day. When the boy is kidnapped, Frank must again take action in order to protect his young "package" and his family. Eventually, Martin unravels a scheme involving biological weapons and the nefarious Gianni Chellini. Martin is forced to remove a bomb from the bottom of his car by executing an aerial corkscrew manoeuver underneath a crane. The crane catches the bomb and Martin escapes unharmed. Frank debuts the [[Audi A8 W12]] in this film. Inspector Tarconi plays an even more prominent role in this film. It is established that he and Frank are now friends, and Tarconi goes as far as to lie to the police to cover for Frank. His cooking prowess is established as well. ===''Transporter 3''=== {{Main|Transporter 3}} Frank has been pressured into transporting Valentina ([[Natalya Rudakova]]) the kidnapped daughter of Leonid Vasilev ([[Jeroen Krabbé]]), the head of the Environmental Protection Agency for Ukraine, from [[Marseille]] through [[Stuttgart]] and [[Budapest]] until he ends up in [[Odessa]] on the [[Black Sea]]. Along the way, with the help of Inspector Tarconi ([[François Berléand]]), Frank has to contend with the people who strong armed him to take the job, agents sent by Vasilev to intercept him, and the general non-cooperation of his passenger, who he realises is the package mid-way through the film. Despite Valentina's cynical disposition and Frank's resistance to get involved, Frank and Valentina fall for each other, while escaping from one life-threatening situation after another. Martin again drives an armoured [[Audi A8 W12]] in the film, as well as a [[BMX]] bicycle. ===''The Transporter Refueled''=== {{main|The Transporter Refueled}} In May 2013, at the [[2013 Cannes Film Festival]], a new reboot trilogy was announced with [[EuropaCorp]] and [[China]]'s [[Fundamental Films]] co-producing and distributing the titles.{{cite news|title='Transporter' sequels announced at Cannes Film Festival|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/movies/news/a483790/transporter-sequels-announced-at-cannes-film-festival.html|accessdate=24 July 2013|newspaper=digitalspy.co.uk|date=22 May 2013}}{{cite news|title=Cannes 2013: Three New Films In The Transporter Franchise Announced|url=http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=37600|accessdate=24 July 2013|newspaper=empireonline.com|date=22 May 2013}} The films will likely be budgeted between $30 million to $40 million each and at least one will be shot in China.{{cite news|title=New Transporter trilogy bound for big screen with parts 4 5 and 6 announced|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/05/22/new-transporter-trilogy-bound-for-big-screen-with-parts-4-5-and-6-announced-3805144/|accessdate=24 July 2013|newspaper=metro.co.uk|date=22 May 2013}} [[Luc Besson]] will co-finance, distribute, produce and write all the films.{{cite news|title=Sequel Bits: ‘Transformers 4’, ‘Expendables 3’, ‘Transporter 4-6’, ‘The Hobbit’, ‘Anchorman 2’, ‘Pacific Rim 2’|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/sequel-bits-transformers-4-expendables-3-transporter-4-6-the-hobbit-anchorman-2-pacific-rim-2/|accessdate=24 July 2013|newspaper=slashfilm.com|date=21 May 2013}} English actor [[Ed Skrein]] replaced Jason Statham as Frank Martin on the fourth installment of the series.{{cite news|title=Transporter 4 will star Ed Skrein in Jason Statham role|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/feb/10/transporter-4-ed-skrein-jason-statham-game-of-thrones|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=theguardian.com|date=10 February 2014}} The fourth film, ''[[The Transporter Refueled]]'', was released in the United States on 4 September 2015 with [[Camille Delamarre]] directing. ==Television== ===''Transporter: The Series''=== {{Main|Transporter: The Series}} ''Transporter: The Series'' is a television series based on the Transporter films which premiered in 2012 on 11 October in Germany on RTL, and on 6 December in France on M6. [[Chris Vance (actor)|Chris Vance]] took over the role of Frank from [[Jason Statham]] and was joined by Hungarian actress [[Andrea Osvárt]], who played Carla, the leading female role in the series,{{cite news |title= Cinemax's 'Transporter' Series Casts Male & Female Leads|first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/05/cinemaxs-transporter-series-casts-male-female-lead/ |newspaper=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=20 May 2011}} starring as a former Intelligence agent who organises his missions, and French actor [[François Berléand]], the only returning actor from the film series, who reprised his role as Inspector Tarconi.{{cite news |title= 'Transporter': 'Lost's' Stephen Williams to Helm Pilot (Exclusive)|first=Lesley |last=Goldberg |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/transporter-losts-stephen-williams-helm-205186 |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |location=Los Angeles, California |date=23 June 2011}} The show was initially supposed to premiere on the cable network Cinemax but Cinemax pulled out due to production problems. TNT picked up the show and aired the 12-episode first season on the TNT network. TNT also ordered a 12-episode second season which aired in the autumn of 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/miptv-transporter-series-reboot-tnt-694443 |title=MIPTV: 'Transporter' Series Reboot for TNT Heavy on Action |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=8 April 2014 |first=Scott |last=Roxborough |accessdate=21 December 2014}} ==Cast and characters== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" width=99% ! rowspan="3" width="19%" | Character ! colspan="4" align="center" | Film ! style="text-align:center;"| TV series |- ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[The Transporter]]'' ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[Transporter 2]]'' ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[Transporter 3]]'' ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[The Transporter Refueled]]'' ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[Transporter: The Series]]'' |- |{{small|'''2002'''}} |{{small|'''2005'''}} |{{small|'''2008'''}} |{{small|'''2015'''}} |{{small|'''2012-2014'''}} |- ! [[Frank Martin (Transporter)|Frank Martin]] | colspan="3" | [[Jason Statham]] | colspan="1" |[[Ed Skrein]] | colspan="1" | [[Chris Vance (actor)|Chris Vance]] |- ! Inspector Marcelle Tarconi | colspan="3" | [[François Berléand]] | colspan="1" style="background:lightgrey;" |   | colspan="1" | [[François Berléand]] |- ! Caterina Boldieu | colspan="4" style="background:lightgrey;" |   | colspan="1" |[[Violante Placido]] |} ==Frank Martin== {{Main | Frank Martin (Transporter) }} '''Frank Martin''' is the [[protagonist]] of the films and television series. He initially serves as a [[reluctant hero]]. He is portrayed as a former [[Special Forces]] operative who was a team leader of a search and destroy unit. His military background includes operations "in and out of" [[Lebanon]], [[Syria]] and [[Sudan]]. He retires from this after becoming fatigued and disenchanted with his superior officers. In simple terms, he got tired of seeing his best efforts turned to nothing by the same people paying him to do the job. So he puts his skills to action as a private driver for hire. ==Reception== ===Box office=== {| class="wikitable sortable" width=99% border="1" style="text-align: center;" ! rowspan="2"| Film ! rowspan="2"| Release date ! colspan="3"| Box office gross ! colspan="2" text="wrap"| Box office ranking ! rowspan="2"| Budget ! rowspan="2"| {{nowrap|{{Abbr|Ref(s)|References}}}} |- ! [[File:Soldiers from Western Canada as cowboys, demonstrating roping (19533044975).jpg|thumb|Trick roping, circa 1914]] [[File:Flóreame... (8696958559).jpg|thumb|A [[charro]] demonstrating trick roping, circa 2013]]
'''Trick roping''' is an entertainment or competitive art involving the spinning of a [[lasso]] also known as a lariat or a "rope." It is particularly associated with [[Wild West Shows|wild west shows]] or western arts in the United States.
The lasso is a well-known tool of American [[cowboy]]s, who developed rope spinning and throwing skills in using lassos to catch animals. Cowboys developed various tricks to show off their prowess with the lasso and demonstrations of these tricks evolved into entertainment and competitive disciplines.
There is a well-established repertoire of tricks that can be divided into three fundamental categories: "flat loop", "vertical loop" and "butterfly". In addition there are thrown loop tricks and tricks that involve the use of two ropes. Among the vertical loop tricks is the "Texas Skip", which involves the performer spinning the lasso in a wide loop in a vertical plane and jumping through the loop from one side to the other on each rotation.<ref>{{citation |url = http://www.juggling.org/books/lasso |last = Bunks |first = Carey D |title = The Lasso: A Rational Guide to Trick Roping |publisher = Carey Bunks (Boston) |year = 1996 |accessdate = 2007-04-16}}</ref>
Well-known trick ropers include:
*[[Texas Jack Omohundro]], the first performer to introduce roping acts to the American stage.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Logan|first1=Herschel C.|title=Buckskin and Satin: The Life of Texas Jack and His Wife|date=1954||page=73|publisher=Stackpole|location=Harrisburg|url=https://archive.org/details/buckskinandstain007287mbp}}</ref>
*[[Montie Montana]], who had a 60-year career as a trick roper, also appeared in several [[John Wayne]] movies.
*Actor and humorist [[Will Rogers]], known for his roles as a cowboy, was an expert at trick roping. Rogers' rope tricks were showcased in the 1922 silent film "The Ropin' Fool."<ref>{{Citation|title = The Ropin' Fool|url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0124857/|date = 1922-10-29|accessdate = 2016-02-23|first = Clarence G.|last = Badger}}</ref>
*Vince Bruce, born April 4, 1955, died September 24, 2011: Internationally acclaimed as one of the best western acts in the world, Bruce made his Broadway debut in 1991, in the Tony Award-winning musical ''The Will Rogers Follies — A Life in Revue''. Appearing as the trick-roping star and portraying Rogers in this tribute to the cowboy and vaudeville star, Bruce remained with the show for two and a half years at New York’s Palace Theatre. For his act, he performed a spin with two ropes, a feat first devised 60 years earlier by Will Rogers himself. On July 21, 1991, at the Empire State Building, Vince set a new world record — 4,011 — for “Texas Skips”.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vince Bruce - Obituaries|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/8818953/Vince-Bruce.html|accessdate=29 December 2017|agency=The Telegraph|date=10 Oct 2011}}</ref>
*[[Florence LaDue|Flores LaDue]] (1883-1951): the only cowgirl to claim three world championships for trick and fancy roping, Flores remained undefeated in the event. Flores and her husband, Guy Weadick, also a Trick Roper, organized and produced the first Calgary Stampede. Flores Ladue is reputed to have been the first trick roper to perform the trick known as the Texas Skip.<ref>{{cite web|title=Flores Ladue|url=http://www.cowgirl.net/portfolios/flores-ladue/|website=National Cowgirl Museum and Hall of Fame|accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref>
*[[Horse trainer]] [[Buck Brannaman]] began his career in a child trick roping act with his brother.

The '''United States Telephone Herald Company''', founded in 1909, was the parent corporation for a number of associated "[[telephone newspaper]]" companies, located throughout the United States, that were organized to provide news and entertainment over telephone lines to subscribing homes and businesses. This was the most ambitious attempt made to develop a distributed audio service prior to the rise of radio broadcasting in the early 1920s.
At least a dozen associate companies were chartered, but despite initial optimism and ambitious goals, only two systems ever went into commercial operation — one based in Newark, New Jersey (New Jersey Telephone Herald, 1911-1912) and the other in Portland, Oregon (Oregon Telephone Herald, 1912-1913). Moreover, both of these systems were shut down after operating for only a short time, due to economic and technical issues.
Corporation activity peaked in 1913, but the lack of success caused the company to suspend operations, and the corporation charter for the United States Telephone Herald Company was repealed in early 1918.
==Company history==
[[File:1910 U.S. Telephone Herald stock certificate.JPEG|300px|thumb|right|United States Telephone Herald Company stock certificate (1910).<ref>Twenty-five $10 shares, issued on November 30, 1910 to John J. Griffin. Signed by James Gillies (treasurer) and Manley M. Gillam (president).</ref>]]
The United States Telephone Herald Company was an authorized offshoot of the [[Telefon Hírmondó]] audio service of Budapest, Hungary. The Telefon Hírmondó programming, transmitted to subscribers over telephone wires, consisted of an extensive selection of news during the day, followed by instruction and entertainment during the evening. This "news-teller" service began operation in February 1893, shortly before the death of its inventor, [[Tivadar Puskás]].
Following a visit to Hungary, Cornelius Balassa procured the U.S. patent rights to the Telefon Hírmondó technology. (Later reports state that the company also held the rights for Canada and Great Britain. Another group obtained the rights for Italy, where in 1910 they established the service under the name [[Araldo Telefonico]]). The formation of a parent U.S. company, initially operating under a New York state charter as the "Telephone Newspaper Company of America", was announced in October 1909, with organizing directors Manley M. Gillam (president), William H. Alexander (secretary and treasurer), and Cornelius Balassa, all of New York City.<ref>[http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald/New%20York%20NY%20Herald%201909/New%20York%20NY%20Herald%201909%20-%209549.pdf" Hark! Telephone Will Tell it All"], ''New York Herald,'' October 7, 1909, page 9 (fultonhistory.com)</ref> In March 1910, the parent company was reorganized as the "United States Telephone Herald Company", now operating as a Delaware-chartered corporation.<ref>[http://www.bizapedia.com/us/UNITED-STATES-TELEPHONE-HERALD-COMPANY.html United States Telephone Herald Company] entry. (bizapedia.com)</ref>
An initial demonstration transmission was given at the company headquarters, located at 110 West Thirty-fourth Street in New York City, in early September 1910.<ref>"News Bulletins by 'Phone", ''New York Times'', September 9, 1910, page 3.</ref> The equipment used was similar to that which was employed in Budapest. As in Hungary, announcers were called "[[stentor]]s", and because [[vacuum tube]] technology had not been developed yet, there were limited methods for amplification, so to compensate the stentors had to speak as loudly as possible into oversized dual-microphones. The lack of amplification also meant that subscribers needed to listen through headphones instead of loudspeakers. On February 14, 1911 {{US patent|src=uspto|984235}}, describing "a telephone system... adapted for supplying innumerable subscribers... general news, musical compositions, and operas, sermons, correct or standard time and other happenings at stated intervals of day and night" was granted to Árpád Németh, and assigned to the company.
Regionally-based Telephone Herald affiliates were authorized for the purpose of creating local "telephone newspaper" systems, with "the parent company to receive a royalty on every instrument installed".<ref name="short">[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiuo.ark:/13960/t3jx22z8w;view=1up;seq=200" 'Phone Herald's Short Life"], ''The Fourth Estate'', March 2, 1912, pages 10, 23.</ref> But ultimately the parent company and its affiliates proved financially unsuccessful, and the United States Telephone Herald Company began winding down operations. Its Delaware business charter was repealed on January 28, 1918, for failure to pay state corporate taxes for two years.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. I'' (1926), page 1263.</ref>
===Telephone Herald associate companies===
At least twelve Telephone Herald associate companies were formed, although in only two cases was a telephone newspaper service successfully launched: the New Jersey Telephone Herald (1911-1912) and the Oregon Telephone Herald (1912-1913). (In some cases the service was also referred to as the "telectrophone".)
Each associate company was established by local owners operating under a state-granted business charter. Publicity for these services commonly stated that the telephone newspaper subscriptions would cost 5 cents a day. (For comparison, at this time a copy of the daily ''Oregonian'' newspaper in Portland also cost 5 cents.) However, a majority of the associate companies got no further than the promotion or demonstration stages.
In addition to twelve known associate companies, early company publicity stated that installations would also be set up in Chicago,<ref>"Newspaper By Phone for Chicago", ''Meriden (Connecticut) Morning Record'', June 15, 1910, page 9.</ref> Scranton, Pennsylvania <ref>"No Private Wires on News Telephone", ''Scranton (Pennsylvania) Republican'', September 29, 1910, page 2.</ref> and Montreal, Canada,<ref>"News and Opera Over Telephone", ''Montreal Gazette'', January 12, 1911, page 1.</ref> but systems do not appear to have been established at any of these locations. Also, a December 14, 1912 advertisement for the Central California Telephone Herald listed associate Telephone Herald companies with company names starting with New York, Chicago, New Orleans, Seattle-Tacoma, Columbia (British Columbia and Alberta, Canada), Los Angeles and Oakland,<ref name=missing>"Central California Telephone Herald" (advertisement), ''Sacramento Bee'', December 14, 1912, page 15.</ref> but there is no information for these either.
==Associate companies that launched telephone newspapers==
===New Jersey Telephone Herald Co. (Newark)===
[[File:1912 NJ Telephone Herald daily schedule.GIF|thumb|right|300px|New Jersey Telephone Herald's daily schedule (1912)<ref name="njth">[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=hvd.32044048678270;view=1up;seq=712 "Telephone Newspaper—A New Marvel"] by Arthur F. Colton, ''Technical World'', February 1912, pages 666-669. Pictured stentor appears to be Richard D. Arons.</ref>]]
Of the two Telephone Herald affiliates which launched commercial services, the '''New Jersey Telephone Herald''' was both the first and most publicized. The company had been incorporated in October 1910 in the state of New Jersey by Eugene Gorenflo, Duncan McIsaac and Nicholas J. Surgess.
The original plan was to begin operations in March 1911, however, the New York Telephone Company, which operated the Newark telephone system franchise, initially refused to lease telephone lines to the Telephone Herald, on the grounds that their charter did not permit it. It required a ruling by the Public Utility Commission to compel the telephone company to provide the needed wires.<ref name="short" /> The hiring process for the stentors, who worked as the news readers, was competitive and rigorous. According to one of the original stentors, the position was restricted to "college men" with strong voices and extensive vocabularies. Throughout the day four stentors announced during rotating shifts of 15 minutes each, and did staff work when they were not announcing.<ref>"America's First Announcer Hailed From Springfield" by Richard D. Arons, ''Springfield (Massachusetts) Sunday Union and Republican'', February 12, 1928, page 34.</ref>
On October 24, 1911, an ambitious daily service, closely patterned after the Telefon Hírmondó's, was launched to a reported fifty receivers located in a department store waiting room, plus five hundred Newark homes. The company's central offices, studio, and switch rooms were located in the Essex Building on Clinton Street in Newark. Condit S. Atkinson, who had extensive newspaper experience, headed the service's news department.<ref>"Editor Atkinson Gets Out First Issue of News by Wire", ''New Brunswick (New Jersey) Times'', October 25, 1911, page 6.</ref>
The company reported that there were many persons eager to sign up with the innovative service, and it soon had more potential subscribers than could be supported. One young listener later remembered that "it was a great thrill to pick up the small receiver and hear a voice telling about world events", moreover, "It was such a novelty that I could scarcely wait to get home from school and listen to it. It fascinated me. I would listen as long as it was operative, or until I was called to do my homework."<ref>''My Father Was Uncle Wiggily'' by Roger Garis, 1966, page 90.</ref> One of the program features was a series of original "Trippertrot" stories, written by local children's author [[Howard R. Garis]], which were later assembled into two book collections: ''Three Little Trippertrots'' and ''Three Little Trippertrots on Their Travels'', published in 1912.
Despite the enthusiastic response, the company soon ran into serious technical and financial difficulties. Due to a revenue crisis, which resulted in employees walking off the job due to missed paychecks, the service was suspended in late February 1912.<ref name="short" /> A replenishment of funding resulted in a temporary revival in late May, with the primary company officials now consisting of Percy Pyne (president), William E. Gunn (vice-president and general manager), and C. E. Danforth (secretary-treasurer), with C. S. Atkinson renewing his editor functions.<ref>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiuo.ark:/13960/t3jx22z8w;view=1up;seq=527 "The Newark Telephone Herald Resumes"], ''The Fourth Estate'', June 1, 1912, page 19.</ref> However, this would only be a temporary respite, and the telephone newspaper transmissions shut down for good in December 1912.
A later review suggested that the primary issue was technical, as the twisted pair phone lines used for the Newark operation had different electrical characteristics than the wiring used by the original Telefon Hírmondó plant.<ref>"Broadcasting in 1912" by G. C. B. Rowe, ''Radio News'', June, 1925, pages 2219, 2309, 2311.</ref> Following the permanent suspension of services, the New Jersey Telephone Herald's business charter was declared null and void on January 18, 1916.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. I'' (1926), page 853.</ref>
{{multiple image|caption_align=center <!-- Essential parameters --> | align = center | direction = horizontal | background color = white
<!-- Header --> | header_background = lightsteelblue | header_align = center | header = '''Publicity photographs for the New Jersey Telephone Herald (Newark, 1912)<ref name="njth" />'''
<!-- Images --> | total_width = 1000 <!--image 1--> | image1 = 1912 New Jersey Telephone Herald stentor.JPEG | width1 = 202 | height1 = 300 | alt1 = | link1 = file:1912 New Jersey Telephone Herald stentor.JPEG | caption1 = '''Stentor (news reader)''' <!--image 2--> | image2 = 1912 New Jersey Telephone Herald entertainers.JPEG | width2 = 420 | height2 = 300 | alt2 = | link2 = file:1912 New Jersey Telephone Herald entertainers.JPEG | caption2 = '''Entertainers''' <!--image 3--> | image3 = 1912 New Jersey Telephone Herald home listeners.JPEG | width3 = 420 | height3 = 300 | alt3 = | link3 = file:1912 New Jersey Telephone Herald home listeners.JPEG | caption3 = '''Home listeners''' <!-- Footer --> | footer_background = white | footer_align = left | footer = }}
===Oregon Telephone Herald Co. (Portland)===
Although less well known than the New Jersey affiliate, the second Telephone Herald company to implement an ongoing telephone newspaper service was the '''Oregon Telephone Herald Company'''. But like its predecessor, it also soon faced financial difficulties and was short-lived. The company was incorporated in Oregon, and headquartered at 506 Royal Building (Seventh and Morrison) in Portland. Extensive demonstrations were begun in May 1912, and advertisements the next month said commercial service would start "around October 1st".<ref name="demos">[http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1912-06-30/ed-1/seq-5/ "Oregon Telephone Herald" (advertisement)], ''The Sunday Oregonian'', June 30, 1912, page 5.</ref>
A January 1913 solicitation for home subscribers for "The Talking Newspaper and Amusement Purveyor" listed the hours of operation as 8:00 AM to midnight.<ref name="orpheum">[https://gallery.multcolib.org/document/lambardi-grand-opera-company-heilig-theatre-november-18-1912 Theater program], Lambardi Grand Opera Company, Heilig Theatre, Portland, Oregon, November 18, 1912.</ref> Later advertisements referred to the service as the "Te-Lec-Tro-Phone", and in April saw the introduction of the reporting of local [[Portland Beavers]] baseball games.<ref name="play">[http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1913-04-14/ed-1/seq-12/ "Everybody-Play Ball" (advertisement)], ''Morning Oregonian'', April 14, 1912, page 12.</ref> (In December, a Northwestern League representative complained that the service had hurt attendance, and supported "the ousting of the various telephone herald and signalling systems from the ball parks"). A promotion the following month offered the chance to hear election results for free at twenty-five business sites.<ref>[http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1913-05-03/ed-1/seq-8/ "Te-lec-tro-phone Election Returns" (advertisement)], ''Portland Oregonian'', May 3, 1913, page 8.</ref> In May, the Portland Hotel advertised that diners could listen to "the latest baseball, business and other news by Telephone-Herald" with their meals.<ref>[http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1913-05-07/ed-1/seq-5/ "The Portland Hotel" (advertisement)], ''Morning Oregonian'', May 7, 1913, page 5.</ref>
There appears to have been a company reorganization in early 1913, and in March two representatives from the parent company, including chief electrical engineer Árpád Németh, were reported in town to give technical advice.<ref>[http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1913-03-16/ed-1/seq-4/ "Phone Device Assured"], ''Morning Oregonian'', March 16, 1913.</ref> But as with its New Jersey predecessor, the Portland enterprise was in trouble. During the summer, Oregon Corporation Commissioner R. A. Watson stepped in, and, under provisions of the state's "Blue Sky Law", barred the Oregon Telephone Herald from doing business,<ref>[http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1913-08-29/ed-1/seq-6/ "Blue Sky Law Applied"], ''Morning Oregonian'', August 29, 1913.</ref> stating that "There was no question about the honesty of this concern, but the scheme isn't practical, and while it might be popular for a short time it would be a failure in the end; therefore, we refused them a permit to sell stock."<ref>"Malheur County Leads State", ''Malheur (Vale, Oregon) Enterprise'', October 25, 1913, pages 1, 6.</ref>
The final advertisements for the company appeared in June 1913, and the state corporation charter was terminated on January 16, 1917, for failure to file statements or pay fees for two years.
{{multiple image|caption_align=center <!-- Essential parameters --> | align = center | direction = horizontal | background color = white
<!-- Header --> | header_background = lightsteelblue | header_align = center | header = '''Advertisements for the Oregon Telephone Herald (Portland)'''
<!-- Images --> | total_width = 1000 <!--image 1--> | image1 = 1912 Oregon Telephone Herald demonstration advertisement.gif | width1 = 768 | height1 = 987 | alt1 = | link1 = file:1912 Oregon Telephone Herald demonstration advertisement.gif | caption1 = '''Demonstrations (1912)'''<ref name="demos" /> <!--image 2--> | image2 = 1913 Oregon Telephone Herald home advertisement.gif | width2 = 943 | height2 = 774 | alt2 = | link2 = file:1913 Oregon Telephone Herald home advertisement.gif | caption2 = '''Home subscribers (1913)'''<ref name="orpheum" /> <!-- Footer --> | footer_background = white | footer_align = left | footer = <!--image 3--> | image3 = 1913 Oregon Telephone Herald baseball advertisement.gif | width3 = 710 | height3 = 1110 | alt3 = | link3 = file:1913 Oregon Telephone Herald baseball advertisement.gif | caption3 = '''Baseball reports (1913)'''<ref name="play" /> }}
==Other associate companies ==
None of the other ten Telephone Herald associate companies launched their proposed telephone newspaper systems, although there were widely varying levels of plans and activities.
===Boston Telephone Herald Syndicate, Inc.===
Incorporated in Massachusetts on April 23, 1913, by Ladislaus de Doory (president), John M. Grosvenor, Jr. (treasurer), and Jesse W. Morton. De Doory was also a promoter with the parent company. However, the syndicate does not appear to have made any demonstrations or other significant development, and its business charter was dissolved on February 21, 1916.
===California Telephone Herald Co. (San Francisco)===
This was the first of two companies that were headquartered in San Francisco, California. The company received a California business charter in February 1911, issued to G. S. Holbrook, W. A. Whelan, W. B. Heckmann, A. H. Vorrath, R. M. Graham, R. Boreman, William T. Newverth, A. C. Gould and A. Jacoby.
Demonstrations were conducted in September 1911 at 821, 822, 823 Head Building, but no further progress appears to have been made, and the company charter was declared forfeited and repealed for non-payment of taxes in February 1915.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. III'' (1930), page 316.</ref>
===Central California Telephone Herald Co. (Sacramento)===
Incorporated in California in February, 1912 by C. J. Ward, F. W. Bresse and S. H. Whisner. Demonstrations were begun on April 2, 1912 from 4th Floor of the Elks' Building.<ref>"Central California Telephone Herald" (advertisement), ''Sacramento Bee'', April 2, 1912, page 11.</ref> In late 1913, provisions were made to lease a local theater, the Diepenbrock, to serve as a source for programming.<ref>"Big Free Concert to Open Diepenbrock", ''Sacramento Bee'', November 19, 1913, page 15.</ref> However, there was an abrupt change of plans, and instead the owners decided to merge their operations with the Pacific Telephone Herald Company.<ref name="merger">"Items of Local Interest", ''Placerville (California) Mountain Democrat'', December 6, 1913, page 1.</ref> The telephone newspaper service never became operational, either before or after the Pacific Telephone Herald merger. The company's charter was declared forfeited and repealed for non-payment of taxes in February 1915.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. III'' (1930), page 364.</ref>
===Massachusetts Telephone Herald Co.===
This company was chartered in Delaware in August 1912 by R. R. Cooling, C. J. Jacobs and H. W. Davis of Wilmington, Delaware. There is no additional information, other than the fact that its corporation charter was repealed on January 24, 1916.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. III'' (1930), page 913.</ref>
===Pacific Telephone Herald Co. (Oakland, California)===
The company was incorporated in California. Demonstrations were made at H. C. Capwell Company's Store beginning in February 1913 which lasted through at least April. The original corporate offices were at 303-304-305 Union Savings Bank Building in Oakland, prior to a relocation to 1741 Franklin Street.
The company's secretary-treasurer, J. B. Whited died in September 1913, and the company president, William Angus, was killed in a mining accident in October 1914. In addition, the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company initially refused to lease telephone lines to the company, resulting in a complaint filed before the Railroad Commission of the State of California. This case was dismissed on November 5, 1913 after the two sides reached a settlement.
In November 1913, a major expansion was announced, with the purchase from the parent company of the rights to operate in twenty-one western U.S. states and "the greater part of southwestern Canada",<ref>"Telephone Herald Co. Acquires Facilities", ''Oakland Tribune'', November 18, 1913, page 18.</ref> and the next month saw a merger with the Central California Telephone Herald Company of Sacramento.<ref name="merger" /> But despite the ambitious expansion plans, it does not appear that any regular service was ever established, and the state business charter was forfeited on March 4, 1916 for failure to pay the state license tax.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. II'' (1928), page 1077.</ref>
===Pennsylvania Telephone Herald Co. (Philadelphia)===
Incorporated in the state of Delaware on December 30, 1911 by Frank Vernon, Ivor B. Blaiberg, and Albert D. Miller. Although there was a limited amount of corporate activity reported in 1912-1913,<ref>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiuo.ark:/13960/t3jx22z8w;view=1up;seq=509 "Philadelphia to Have a Telephone Herald"], ''The Fourth Estate'', May 25, 1912, page 19.</ref> nothing of significance appears to have resulted. The corporation charter was repealed on January 25, 1917 for two years taxes unpaid.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. I'' (1926), page 955.</ref>
===San Diego Telephone Herald Co.===
Incorporated in California in August 1911 by H. A. Schmidt (president), M. N. Schmidt and G. Stephens. The principals were inspired by the reported success of the concept in San Francisco, and promotional advertisements were run in the fall of 1911,<ref>"One Who Knows the Telephone Herald" (advertisement), ''San Diego Union'', October 29, 1911, page 32.</ref> but the enterprise never began operations.
===San Francisco Telephone Herald Co.===
This was second San Francisco-based Telephone Herald company, following the earlier California Telephone Herald Company. It was incorporated in the state of California on October 29, 1912, with founding the directors of W. H. Dohrmann, J. F. Dohrmann, A. J. Beecher, F. W. Beecher, Thomas R. White, C. E. Youngblood, Rudolph Schlueten, Clarence Eppstein and E. L. Manner.
Demonstrations were given at 687 Market Street in early January 1913, but no further progress appears to have been made. The corporation charter was forfeited November 30, 1913, for failure to pay the state license tax.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. II'' (1928), page 1226.</ref>
===Southern California Telephone Herald Co. (Los Angeles)===
One of the first associate companies to be formed, this was also, due to fraud, one of the first to fail. It was chartered in California in May 1911, led by Peter Archbold Gordon Grimes, who turned out to be a con man. Grimes soon ran off with company funds, and was next seen impersonating an aviator in Hawaii.<ref>[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1912-07-26/ed-1/seq-6/" 'Kenneth Gordon, Aviator' Turns Out to Be Plain Peter Grimes",] ''The Hawaiian Gazette'', July 26, 1912, page 6.</ref> The corporation charter was forfeited on November 30, 1911 for failure to pay its state license tax.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. I'' (1926), page 1140.</ref>
===Washington Telephone Herald Co. (Seattle)===
This affiliate, capitalized with $500,000 of common stock, was chartered in the state of Washington in June, 1911. The officers were Sherwood Gillespy, president; B. J. Klarman, vice president; and N. R. Solner, secretary and treasurer.<ref>"Tube in Wall to Tell All News", ''Seattle Post-Intelligencer'', June 7, 1911, page 11.</ref> It was also announced that demonstrations were being conducted at the company headquarters at 339-340-341 Henry building.<ref>"Washington Telephone Herald Company" (advertisement) ''Seattle Post-Intelligencer'', June 11, 1911, page 17.</ref> The company soon faced financial difficulties, and in October was forced into receivership due to a salary dispute.<ref>"Receiver for Telephone Herald", ''Seattle Post-Intelligencer'', October 4, 1911, page 5; "Two Receivers are Appointed", ''Seattle Post-Intelligencer'', October 8, 1911, page 4.</ref> The company charter was cancelled sometime during the biennial reporting period of October 1, 1912 to September 30, 1914, for failure to pay the annual state license fee.<ref>''Marvyn Scudder Manual of Extinct or Obsolete Companies: Vol. III'' (1930), page 1422.</ref>

==Legacy==
There were a few other early attempts to set up telephone-based news and entertainment systems in the United States, including the [[Tellevent]], which conducted demonstrations and experimental work in Michigan from 1906-1908, and the [[Automatic Electric|Automatic Electric Company's]] [[Musolaphone]], which operated a short-lived entertainment system in Chicago in 1913. However, these efforts were no more successful than the Telephone Herald companies.
Both the Hungarian [[Telefon Hírmondó]] and the Italian [[Araldo Telefonico]] survived long enough for their operations to be combined with radio broadcasting in the 1920s. The same did not occur in the United States, and the Telephone Herald companies were the last early effort to offer nationwide audio programming over telephone lines. Although the concept of home audio entertainment was attractive to potential U.S. subscribers, the lack of signal amplification and other technical limitations, such as the need to maintain a telephone line infrastructure, and having to listen over headphones, made the technology unprofitable.<ref>"Early Uses of the Telephone" by Carolyn Marvin, ''Communication in History'', 1995, page 179.</ref>
Less than a decade after the failure of the Telephone Herald companies, radio broadcasting was developed, which had the significant advantage that it could dispense with the need to use telephone lines. Moreover, radio programming could be provided free of subscription fees, because selling airtime to advertisers, the financing method most commonly adopted in the United States, provided sufficient revenue for ongoing operations.
